newsitem.title: INDIA: India's ITC profits seen rising sharply.
newsitem.headline: India's ITC profits seen rising sharply.

text.p: Indian tobacco conglomerate ITC Ltd will report sharply higher profits for fiscal 1996/97 (April-March) led by robust growth in cigarette sales and improved margins, analysts said on Monday.

"Strong cigarette sales growth, expansion of margins and the possibility of lower write-offs would boost profits," said Sandeep Bhatia, ITC analyst at UBS Securities, the investment arm of Union Bank of Switzerland.
The results are due on Tuesday.
ITC is one of India's top 10 private companies. Britain's BAT Industries Plc hold 31.7 percent equity in the firm.
He forecast net profit to jump 41 percent to 3.67 billion rupees as the company is benefited from hiving off, or closing down, loss-making ventures.
Profit in 1995/96 had fallen to 2.61 billion rupees from 2.62 billion the year before, due to loss-making deals in farm products and global trade.
Analysts expect 1996/97 profits to reflect the strong margins in tobacco and cigarette sales.
Net profit forecasted by analysts range from 3.4 billion rupees to 4.0 billion rupees.
"We expect the results to be extremely good," said K. Ramachandran, analyst at Birla Marlin Securities. "We are forecasting a net profit of 3.98 billion rupees."
He saw cigarette volume sales growth of 10 percent and margins rising 7.0 percent.
Mayank Khemka, research head at Calcutta-based brokerage C. Mackertich, said profits would depend on how the company accounts for excise claims which were under litigation.
ITC has made a deposit of 3.5 billion rupees against excise claims which the firm shows as current asset but could write-off, he said.
But Rajesh Mayani, analyst at HSBC Batlivala & Karani Securities, said a write-off was unlikely so long as the case was still pending.
He expects a net profit of 3.4 billion rupees depending on how a restructuring of agro-businesses impacted the company.
Analysts do not expect the firm to announce a bonus equity issue though there have been rumours in the stock markets.
"We believe that a bonus issue and moreover in the ratio of 1:1 is unlikely," Mayani said in a report.
"We have been bullish on the company without any expectations of a bonus, and an issue at this point would only further boost our confidence in the stock," he said.
ITC closed at 448.25, up 6.25 rupees on the Bombay Stock Exchange.
